awd_titl_txt: Designing a Middle Grades Spatial Skills Curriculum
awd_abstract_narration:
The ability to make spatial judgements and visualize has been shown to be a strong indicator of students' future success in STEM-related courses. The project is innovative because it uses a widely available gaming environment, Minecraft, to examine spatial reasoning. Finding learning experiences which support students' spatial reasoning in an authentic and engaging way is a challenge in the field. This project will create a portable training system that can be easily deployed in middle grades (5th - 7th grade) as a prototype for increasing students' spatial reasoning skills. The project will study gender differences in spatial reasoning and examine how learning experiences can be designed to develop spatial skills using Minecraft as a platform. The resources will incorporate hands-on learning and engage students in building virtual structures using spatial reasoning. The curriculum materials are being designed to be useful in other middle grades contexts. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

The study is a design and development study that will design four training modules intended to improve spatial reasoning in the following areas: rotation, mental slicing, 2D to 3D transformation and perspective taking. The research questions are: (1) Does a Minecraft-based intervention that targets specific spatial reasoning tasks improve middle grade learners' spatial ability? (2) Does spatial skills growth differ by gender? The experimental design will compare the influence of the virtual spatial learning environment alone vs. the use of design challenges designed specifically for the spatial skills. The data collected will include assessments of spatial reasoning and feedback from teachers' who use the materials. The spatial skills measures will be administered as a pre-test, post-test, and six-month follow-up assessment to measure long term effects.

por.por_cntn:
For our 3-year "Design and Development", we hypothesized that using a 3D-based environment like Minecraft might provide one approach for developing spatial skills interventions for middle grade learners. We set out to develop an early version functional prototype of Minecraft-based game that would be the focus of a series of summer camps delivered in 2018 and 2019. At these camps, participants engaged in Minecraft-based activities designed to target two spatial skills: mental rotation and 2D-to-3D transformation. For the first summer camp offered in 2018, we constructed tutorial-style pilot modules in Minecraft to support the development of those two skills. Learners joined our spatial skill "world" in Minecraft and completed a series mental rotation and 2d-to-3d transformation tasks, building their "solutions" to the spatial skills problems. Findings indicate that students scored significantly higher on the mental rotation post-test, but not on the 2D-to-3D post-test. We were particularly interested in gender differences with spatial skills development, but when isolated for gender, no significant differences were found between male and female-identifying learners. Qualitative data suggested that learners desired a more engaging game structure for the spatial skills activities with a less tutorial/drill-and-practice structure. Teacher consultants corroborated these findings.

For the second iteration of the game design, we reinvented the design to make the activities more engaging for learners and less drill-and-practice oriented. To do this, we authored a fantasy-world storyline to drive the spatial skill activities. Participants in the second camp were given a narrative that guided them through mazes and puzzles in which they had to apply spatial skills to be successful. The goal of this storyline was to solve the puzzles to obtain artifacts and maps needed to defend themselves. We integrated a variety of scaffolds that included hands-on non-screen-based spatial skills activities to better support learners' diverse needs in practicing those spatial skills. Although findings suggest that the storyline approach was more engaging than our first iteration, no significant spatial skill growth was detected. When isolated for gender, no significant differences were found. Additional data was collected on students reported confidence in solving the spatial skill puzzles and the time it took them to complete each puzzle. Despite no significant changes in confidence, participants were able to complete both the rotation and the 2D-to-3D transformation test significantly quicker at the end of the camp.

Our research team then directed our efforts on a third iteration of the game and alternative platforms for game delivery. We recognized the considerable technical burden with the Minecraft-based platform where an advanced level of Minecraft administrator expertise was needed to manage learners' gameplay. In response to this challenge, a web-based early prototype was developed that could be accessible on any platform via a web-browser. Further, partner teachers shared that, while they see the considerable value in addressing learners' spatial skills, the time constraints presented in a standard classroom require alignment of those activities to other content areas. Therefore, our research team constructed an accompanying standards-based framework prototype for the game directly aligned gameplay with math and ELA.

In terms of intellectual merit, our project has contributed to understandings of how the integration of digital games can be used to teach spatial skills critical to achievement in STEM. We learned that that when the game was structured more like a tutorial/drill-and-practice game, learners did increase their mental rotation skills despite their lack of engagement with the spatial skill activities. Conversely, when we integrated a storyline approach, we detected no spatial skill growth despite higher learner engagement. Findings also indicate that learners completed puzzles more quickly after playing the spatial skills game. We learned that teaching spatial skills must be integrated into other content areas like math and ELA to be considered feasible by practitioners, and that the Minecraft platform was too cumbersome for most educators. Combined, these results suggest that a hybrid game design might be in order. This design could be web-based, include a balance between tutorial/drill-and-practice activities, include computer-based and hands-on scaffolds, built upon a storyline or narrative to better engage learners, and include strong interdisciplinary connections.

Our project has achieved several broader impacts. First, our project has shown promise for the next iteration of our game that could be a widely and easily distributed web-based game to support critical spatial skill development in middle grade learners. Secondly, our camps provided almost 60 middle grade learners ranging from grades 4th through 7th opportunities for spatial skill development. Further, our project provided spatial skill professional development opportunities for nine undergraduate students (4 STEM majors; 5 education majors), two graduate students (one physics PhD student; one education PhD student), and two partner teachers (3rd and 5th grade), all of whom helped deliver the summer camps, provide expert consultation, and assist in the design and development of the spatial skill games.
